text: Question that I might turn into a blog post if anyone has any interesting answers: Should you put an author on a company blog post?

elements.text: Question that I might turn into a blog post if anyone has any interesting answers: Should you put an author on a company blog post?

text: Yep. It creates a 1:1 relationship. Otherwise, it looks like some soulless entity wrote it. Folks want PEOPLE to write articles and the author bio section enables that.

elements.text: Yep. It creates a 1:1 relationship. Otherwise, it looks like some soulless entity wrote it. Folks want PEOPLE to write articles and the author bio section enables that.

text: Absolutely you should! It lends credibility both to the writing (as it shows the writer is an expert in their field (usually)), and it gives the author bylined content which helps position them as an expert offsite

elements.text: Absolutely you should! It lends credibility both to the writing (as it shows the writer is an expert in their field (usually)), and it gives the author bylined content which helps position them as an expert offsite

text: Yes, definitely. It shows the person behind the article, they can be contacted, adds to the author authority etc.

elements.text: Yes, definitely. It shows the person behind the article, they can be contacted, adds to the author authority etc.

text: *Waits patiently for someone to say no*

elements.text: Waits patiently for someone to say no

text: Yep totally. We even mention our freelance writers’ names when their articles go live. Giving credibility to the person enhances productivity, builds a 1:1 relationship, and also shows empathy as a brand... where a brand grows along with their employees. Its about mutual growth, and this is one great way to facilitate it.

text:
:smiling_imp: Devil's advocate: people come primarily for the content, not the byline. If there's high turnover in the co of you're outsourcing and someone's name gets attached to something really off brand, the teeny bits of goodwill built could be cancelled out by the (teeny) bits of risk.

Also, if the brand itself has a strong personality, it might be worth having the post come from it (e.g. something written by Old Spice itself would feel natural, vs [Regular Name]).

Also, if the brand itself has a strong personality, it might be worth having the post come from it (e.g. something written by Old Spice itself would feel natural, vs [Regular Name]).

text: Anyone with experience building community/audience -- how do you do it, and what methods have been most successful?

elements.text: Anyone with experience building community/audience -- how do you do it, and what methods have been most successful?

text:
That’s the magic question eh Theresa? I will say that an audience and a community are very different and would require different strategies.

When starting, *I’d say the best method is to pick a platform and share on it daily for a year.* After that year, reassess what’s working and what’s not.

Building an audience takes longer than you’d expect but leads to more opportunities than you’d ever imagine.

Anyone pushing methods to do it quickly without effort is trying to make money off you (I learned this the hard way). Beware.

I wrote about my experience getting started: <https://stewarthillhouse.com/building-audience-6-months/>

Hope that helps!

attachments.title: The First 180 Days Building an Audience - 5 Lessons Learned
attachments.text: At the end of 2019, I decided to begin getting serious about building a personal audience. My driving reason: to be able to travel anywhere in the world and be able to get a beer with a local who follows my work. And while that reason might seem strange, it
attachments.fallback: Stewart Hillhouse: The First 180 Days Building an Audience - 5 Lessons Learned

When starting,
I’d say the best method is to pick a platform and share on it daily for a year.

After that year, reassess what’s working and what’s not.

text:
For communities, patience and consistency are important. I'm taking actual online communities, not when the word "community" is subbed in for "our followers" or "the userbase."

Communities will develop norms, rituals, and self policing if the regularss and superusers truly care about whatever it is they've rallied around. As an admin or mod, you do well to nurture bottom-up development ("hiring" superusers to moderator positions is a good way to do this).

All this can take years. It's not really a community if there's been no time for people to gel, no time for ritual to be established, etc.

You need probably 1,000 users + a steady stream of growth before you'll see a budding community. There's a loose stat around 89-9-1.

89% of users lurk and contribute no content
9% create 50% of the content; these are your active members
1% creates the other 50%; these are the regs & superusers

Regs/supers will churn, but some stick around for years, depending what it is.

All this can take years. It's not really a community if there's been no time for people to gel, no time for ritual to be established, etc.

text: <@U01AHL8AGBB> How does one even get started with that?

elements.text: How does one even get started with that?

text:
And I think traditional BBS forums are the single best platform for forming real communities (see: reddit).

Chronological conversation without any feed or algo trying to decide what people need to see allows the users to drive what they see and what they care about.

Social feeds also tend to try and show "the most relevant" comments. People invested in their community want the whole record of conversation. Threaded versions can certainly work if done well (see again, reddit)

Platforms like Slack do an okay job, as I can scroll to see past convos and they thread. But I'd prefer reverse chrono with newly commented threads appearing at the top (am biased towards bbs' tho...)

text:
First, I'd establish a founding group of people who are happy to geek about topic X. Topic X needs to be a real thing, not some business KPI or brand ideal.

I'd try and set up a forum, or maybe a slack group. There are modern alternatives like <https://www.discourse.org/> and <https://circle.so>.

Then find other pockets of geekdom in and around the area of Topic X. Sleuth out folks on social that are posting about it and invite them in, growing that core of Topic X geeks.

If you're formally trying to grow the community vs having fun talking to Topic X geeks, someone(s) should have a marketing hat on and devote time/resources to content-ifying the passionate geek discussions and plugging it into the various strategies that you see in this Slack Group.

If there's money and budget, one day you might advertise but I'd probably opt to spend it on quality of life features for the community or in fuelling quality headhunting for more members

text:
Have been researching this a lot for a community we're launching in the home & garden space. Not an expert by any means, but Stewart's comment regarding posting daily for a year is basically what most other people's advice comes out to.

I've found that some of the paid community platforms, eg Mighty Networks and some mentioned above, have good templates and checklists they've published as part of their own content marketing programs, that have made it super easy for us to get some of this work done. In the case of Mighty Networks they have a few brainstorming sheets for nailing down community purpose / why we're here, and scheduling ahead for upcoming topics and Q&As, that made it easier for us to get this launch process started.

YES

text:
Absolutely:

Giving your writers bylines helps to boost their reach and credibility. Happy writers keep writing for you. 

Working with a well-known writer in your space builds your authority and improves your reach because you have access to the writer’s network. 

Bylines help readers connect to the writer behind the post - building engagement.
People want to be connected human to human - that’s hard to do without a face and a ‘story’ behind each post.

elements.text: Absolutely:

Working with a well-known writer in your space builds your authority and improves your reach because you have access to the writer’s network.

People want to be connected human to human - that’s hard to do without a face and a ‘story’ behind each post.

text:
:wave:  Hey Taylor! this isn’t concrete research per se. BUT perhaps a good launching point to make your case that Instagram >< retirees is a _terrible_ idea:

• <https://www.socialmediatoday.com/news/how-different-generations-of-consumers-use-social-media-infographic/576243/|How Different Generations Of Consumers Consume Social Media>
• <https://www.postbeyond.com/social-media-generations-2/|Social Media for Every Generation>
• <https://www.visualcapitalist.com/visualizing-social-media-use-by-generation/|Visualizing Social Media Use By Generation>
Along the lines of your last comment - request that your client take some time to run a survey to the target persona groups asking: which social media platform do you use most and for what? *This at least gives you some on the ground data to validate your hypothesis versus theirs.*

There’s a huge misconception that whatever buyer personas can be addressed by multiple social accounts run by brands :sweat_smile:

Maintaining a social presence that will yield _any_ ROI = investing legit time and people resources. Don’t start without at least some idea of goal(s) and strategy! The fundamental thing that people go on social media for is to be _social_ not to interact with brands and get sold to - esp if you’re talking about _personal_ finance.

Perhaps a better gameplan here is to see if you can shift the thinking towards influencer marketing for this demographic and getting some SMEs in to address key concerns in the personal finance for retiree space, then build a brand narrative around that + release via the appropriate social channel on ONE branded platform to build credibility at the top of the funnel. Perhaps an invite-only Facebook group for people to discuss main pain points?

(excuse my passion here _- it’s like “hey I can SEE the iceberg, lets swerve around!!“)_ 

Hope this is helpful and good luck. :100: :100: :100:  push back and get some data on finding their platform. So key before you start investing any resources.

text:
At a brand content role two lifetimes ago (2016), we experienced increasing Legal scrutiny due to ongoing litigation, going public, and eventually an M&A. Luckily, we had the NICEST lead  attorney ever (seriously).

He took the time to meet with us several times to discuss (in a very collaborative way) the statements, phrases, and marketing claims that were problematic from a litigation standpoint vs. what's considered "fluffery" (his words).

Highly recommend trying a collaborative "teach me" approach if your legal team is available to do so.

elements.text:

Highly recommend trying a collaborative "teach me" approach if your legal team is available to do so.

text:
Yes and no. From my startup POV, yes for ghostwritten posts for co-founders who represent the brand, have strong alignment to your ICP, and  the content goes deeper than 101-level understanding.

IMO, no, or not necessarily, if it's entry-level SEO-focused content that may diminish their personal brands (listicles, what is ____? content, 7 steps to XYZ).

text:
<@UJS103D7S> Thanks, that’s good insight. I think if I could start all of this over (we went public in summer so the increased legal review began 6+ months ago) I would start there. We tried, but had I known then what I know now, I would have had a whoooooole LOT more questions to ask.

The scope of the legal reviews have been steadily increasing as they’ve added legal headcount, and now writers are being asked to submit a high level of backup to support claims like, literal example, “Digitally native disruptors are entering the market at an accelerated pace.” To have that reviewed at the same level of intensity as a quantifiable claim about our actual product (especially at the scale we produce content) seems… excessive.

The conversation around fixing the process has been escalated to above my paygrade, thankfully, but I was hoping to learn about how the process works at other companies both as a temperature check and to offer potential recommendations. But of course now it just feels like I’m whining :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

The scope of the legal reviews have been steadily increasing as they’ve added legal headcount, and now writers are being asked to submit a high level of backup to support claims like, literal example, “Digitally native disruptors are entering the market at an accelerated pace.” To have that reviewed at the same level of intensity as a quantifiable claim about our actual product (especially at the scale we produce content) seems… excessive.

The conversation around fixing the process has been escalated to above my paygrade, thankfully, but I was hoping to learn about how the process works at other companies both as a temperature check and to offer potential recommendations. But of course now it just feels like I’m whining

text: <@UJE5LQ2JC>, I generally strongly recommend having both on the same CMS (and I've always done this whenever it's been my choice). The reasoning behind having 2 CMSes is generally that you want a different workflow for more static pages like the homepage, as opposed to templated pages like blog posts. But it’s hard to keep design and other important aspects of 2 CMSes in sync, so you end up looking like you have 2 slightly different sites, which causes a visitor experience that reflects poorly on your brand – plus you end up on 2 separate subdomains. And really for very little advantage unless you have lots of dev resources.

And really for very little advantage unless you have lots of dev resources.
